CHOPSTICKS: A particular East Asian eating utensil, used in pairs and held in the hand. The utensil is a stick, usually made of wood and measuring approximately 23cm (10 inches) in length.
FORK: A pronged tool having a long straight handle, used for digging, lifting, throwing etc.
KNIFE: A utensil or a tool designed for cutting, consisting of a flat piece of hard material, usually steel or other metal (the blade), usually sharpened on one edge, attached to a handle. The blade may be pointed for piercing.
SKEWER: A long pin, normally made of metal or wood, used to secure food during cooking.
SPOON: An implement for eating or serving; a scooped utensil whose long handle is straight, in contrast to a ladle.
SPORK: An eating utensil shaped like a spoon, the bowl of which is divided into tines like those of a fork, and so has the function of both implements; some _____s have a serrated edge so they can also function as a knife.
TONGS: An instrument or tool used for picking things up without touching them with the hands or fingers, consisting of two slats or grips hinged at the end or in the middle, and sometimes including a spring to open the grips.
